#Text=2. Preliminaries
#Text=2.1. Threat Model
#Text=The current work places no limitations on the attacker .
#Text=Eavesdropping , injecting data into the communication stream or stopping the stream itself are feasible .
#Text=Thus , for every route under her control , she can drop packets ( dos ) or taint the data to initiate a mitm attack .
#Text=We allow attackers to collude , bringing under their joint control multiple routes .
#Text=For simplicity ’s sake , we will refer to all of the colluding parties as one entity .
#Text=2.2. Assumptions and Definitions
#Text=To allow for communication , the only prior knowledge assumed is the address of both parties .
#Text=This address can be in any form : ip address , unique imei embedded in the device , or phone number allocated to the smart node .
#Text=To avoid collisions , we assume that this address is unique and cannot be spoofed .
#Text=To justify this assumption , we note that spoofing an address only influences some of the routing tables ; not all of them .
#Text=This allows for the correct delivery of packets not traveling through malicious nodes .
#Text=Last , no trusted third party ( ttp ) is available for the coordination or authentication of sender and receiver .
#Text=Definition 1.
#Text=Let be a topology graph of a manet at a specific time , where are the hosts in the network , and are the bidirectional communication links between these hosts .
#Text=Let be a noncyclic route ( ) in G , between the sender ( ) and receiver ( ) .
#Text=Let denote the length of the path .
#Text=Let denote the set of all possible such routes , the size of , and the set of chosen routes from ; implying , .
#Text=Let , such that and , , which is under the attacker ’s control .
#Text=Let equal the size of A.
#Text=In essence , we define that it suffices for one host , , to come under the attacker ’s control for the entire route , , to be tainted .
#Text=Definition 2.
#Text=Let .
#Text=That is , denoting all the paths not under the attacker ’s control .
#Text=Let be the size of F.
#Text=Based on the above definition , we assume that the manet is such that , meaning that at least one route between the sender and receiver is not under the attacker ’s control .
#Text=That the attacker has not taken over the entire network , for which no leap of faith algorithms can succeed .
#Text=2.3. Simulation Parameters
#Text=Prior to implementing our algorithm on a real-world manet application ( e.g. , Serval ) , we ran multiple preliminary simulations to test its feasibility .
#Text=In this section , we describe our simulation model .
#Text=2.3.1. Random Number Generator
#Text=All simulations must have the means of generating random data .

#Text=Of the many algorithms available ( e.g. , Mersenne Twister ) , we chose the combined multiple recursive random number generator ( cmrg ) algorithm , an algorithm that passed a wide range of empirical tests of randomness and is the algorithm of choice in many simulation software ( e.g. , Arena ) .
#Text=Of course , similar results should be achieved using all good random number generators .
#Text=Mobility Model
#Text=The mobility of nodes in the real world exhibits vastly varying behaviors .
#Text=Some walk , others drive .
#Text=Some move about randomly , others in specific formations or patterns .
#Text=Each of these have their own characteristics , and must be modelled accordingly ( for a survey see ) .
#Text=Due to its prevalence ( see , e.g. , ) , in this work , all simulations followed a random walk model , which captures the pattern of people in open spaces or recreational parks .
#Text=We leave other models to future research .
#Text=2.3.3. Routing Algorithm
#Text=Network simulation requires that one choose the means by which packets are forwarded on the path to the destination .
#Text=Being the basis behind ospf , implementation of the Dijkstra graph theory best route algorithm using standard dynamic programming techniques , allows us to find the optimal ( shortest ) route .
#Text=We randomly chose between multiple paths having similar lengths , classifying one as the better of the bunch .
#Text=All packets were sent through optimal paths when possible .
#Text=2.3.4. Attacker Dispersion
#Text=Attackers are randomly placed on the graph , allowing for all possible attacker dispersion scenarios .
#Text=The number of attackers are a function of the size of the population , with a linear increase in the population entailing a similar increase in the number of attackers .
#Text=These attackers are assumed colluding .
#Text=Knowledge gleaned by one attacker ( e.g. , intercept of a micro-ke message ) and/or spoofing requirements are instantly shared with all others through external means .
#Text=Simulation Round
#Text=Each round was preset with a specific combination of parameters that we are checking for ( see Section 3.3 and Section 4.2 ) .
#Text=Next , we randomly chose some of the nodes in the network to represent colluding attackers ; their specific number a function of predetermined parameter .
#Text=Last , assuming there is a connection between sender and receiver , , we sprayed the k micro-ke messages documenting whether all , none , or some of the messages were intercepted .
#Text=Rounds for which , were discarded .
#Text=The actual spraying algorithm was done using either random message spraying or even message spraying algorithm ( see Section 3.2 ) .
#Text=Both techniques were executed on the same network graph so we can get comparable results .
